Hi Ian,

Many game developers do publish papers nowadays. I guess the AAAI
"Challenges in Game AI Workshop" gets the most submissions (and is the
most relevant to modern day computer game dev) but there is also the
IEEE CIG symposium, which is of interest. I'm sure there are others.

Here's are a couple of links for you

http://csapps.essex.ac.uk/cig/

http://www.simbionic.com/gameai/schedule.html

Regards

Mat Buckland

 

-----Original Message-----
From: neat@yahoogroups.com [mailto:neat@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
Ian Badcoe
Sent: Tuesday, October 11, 2005 3:01 PM
To: neat@yahoogroups.com
Subject: [neat] Publish and be damned?

Hi,
	I experiment with NEAT purely because I enjoy it, and I think
there 
is some good progress to be made on a reasonable time-frame.

	And for the purposes of that, there is no need for me to do
anything 
more than write the odd web-page (very odd, in all probability :) and 
post things here.

	BUT, with half an eye on the future, I might want to get back
into 
academia one day (say if its raining and I happen to be passing a 
university), and to do that, you really do have to have a 
track-record of publications you can point at.  I know this to be a 
particularly acute problem (at least here in the UK) because I tried 
it a few years ago and, even explaining that I hadn't published 
anything because the games industry is paranoid and _never_ publishes 
anything (this 99.5% true) I still couldn't get them to rate me.

	SO, I'd quite like to publish some of my current work (when it
gets 
results that is, but the reason I mention this now is that at the 
moment its looking very promising).  And I was wondering what people 
thought the prospects are.  I mean, do journals generally have a rule 
that says you have to be a member of a university before they'll look 
at your work?  I'm guessing not because, of course, many corporate 
R&D depts also regularly publish.  But what are the prospects for an 
unknown individual?  Would your submission get the same treatment as 
anybody's?  Or would they throw it on a "possible loonies" pile and 
forget about it?

	Would I need somebody in a university to "front" it for me --
e.g. 
list themselves as the corresponding author and me as the co-author 
of the work?  If that's the case, I would be quite open to the idea, 
I mean it even seems reasonably honest, not really different from 
putting your laboratory head on your papers because he provided the 
environment in which the work happened (even if he actually 
understand nothing of your work -- this used to happen in 
biochemistry, mentioning no names...).

	Opinions?

	Ian

	

In fifteen minutes, everybody will be in the future.
